Looking back on his life, we should all be thankful for Sam Johnson‚Äôs relentless heart of service. This is a huge loss for the great state of Texas, and it was an honor to serve with him.
I remember how he had difficulty punching his voting card on the House floor because he had been injured so badly in the war, but he always showed up for his country.

Sam told me that when the military was testing the effects of nuclear explosions on planes, he volunteered to fly over 5 nuclear explosions. Sam went on to become a respected conservative leader in Congress.

After being shot down in Vietnam in 1966, Sam was taken prisoner and tortured for nearly 7 YEARS ‚Äì including 2.5 years spent in leg irons. After all that, he immediately showed up in line, reporting for duty.

My heart breaks for the loss of my former colleague and a true American hero, Sam Johnson. Sam flew 62 missions as a Thunderbird, the Air Force‚Äôs world-renowned precision flying demonstration team, during the Korean War and 25 missions during the Vietnam War.

2/4

There needs to be answers, accountability, and charges.

This seat in the U.S. Senate belongs to all Minnesotans, and especially the unheard who wait for the justice they deserve, and I will use it to lift up their voices, and their families, and their experiences.
This community is ALL of our community ‚Äî and part of our community is hurting. The only way we are all safe is to acknowledge what happened and work to seek justice.
I will work for justice to be served for George Floyd, and I will fight to fix the systems that allow this injustice to be perpetuated.
Hoping this will get better is not a strategy. We need to address the systems of oppression that perpetuate this violence and that failed to provide justice to Jamar Clark and Philando Castile.

Our work is to root out the culture of racism and abuse of power at the heart of a system that allows the Black community and so many other marginalized communities to be killed, abused, and taunted by law enforcement over and over again.
To make it right, we need consequences and accountability, not explanations. We won‚Äôt get there through ‚Äúbetter training‚Äù or ‚Äúimproved policies and procedures.‚Äù
I have spoken with many community members and leaders over the past few days. As Reverend Billy Russell said to me, ‚ÄúWe need to make it right. It‚Äôs not right now, but we need to make it right.‚Äù

We cannot look away from the reality that a woman, Breonna Taylor, was killed by police in her home in Louisville. This is not a single instance ‚Äî it's a repeated pattern that goes against our humanity and everything we know is right.
We cannot look away from the reality that a man was killed by a police officer, while others watched him plead for his life.

As a country, we have so much difficulty facing the racism that is our history, and this is true also in Minnesota. When we see it, we explain or turn away rather than facing the injustice full on. In this moment, we need to break through that.

I feel deeply saddened by what is happening in the city that I love, the state I love, the place where we raised our kids ‚Äî but I know it‚Äôs because we haven‚Äôt acknowledged and done the work to face the systemic problems rooted deep in our history.
Dr. King once said, "a riot is the language of the unheard. And what is it that America has failed to hear? ... It has failed to hear that the promises of freedom and justice have not been met."

After the murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis on Monday, I have heard the pain and grief, the anger and exhaustion of people in our community, crying out in response to this devastating loss of life by the police who have sworn to protect and defend us.
